trans-unit.source: Provides data for the **Navigating** event.
These event arguments contain information about the navigation that was requested, and are passed to handlers of the **Navigating** event, which is implemented by the following:
<xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs> encapsulates the following details of the navigation request:

**Navigation Initiation**: <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.NavigationMode%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.Navigator%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.IsNavigationInitiator%2A>.
**Navigation Content**: <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.Uri%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.Content%2A>.
**Navigation Request**: <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationFailedEventArgs.WebRequest%2A>.

**Navigation State**: <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.ExtraData%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.ContentStateToSave%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.TargetContentState%2A>.
This information allows you to both evaluate the nature of the navigation request, and view and update specified request details before navigation occurs.

Based on the navigation request information provided by <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs>, or based on application-specific state or code, you can completely prevent navigation by setting the <xref:System.ComponentModel.CancelEventArgs.Cancel%2A> property to `true` (by default, <xref:System.ComponentModel.CancelEventArgs.Cancel%2A> is `false`).
Gets a reference to the content object that is being navigated to.
You can navigate to content using either a [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_uri](~/includes/tlasharptla-uri-md.md)] or an object.

When navigating to an object, which occurs when calling <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationService.Navigate%2A?displayProperty=fullName> and <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationService.Navigate%2A?displayProperty=fullName>, <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.Content%2A> contains a reference to the content object that is being navigated to.
Additionally, the <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.Uri%2A> property will be `null`.
A <xref href="System.Object"></xref> reference to the content object that is being navigated to; otherwise, `null`.
Gets and sets the <xref href="System.Windows.Navigation.CustomContentState"></xref> object that is associated with the back navigation history entry for the page being navigated from.
<xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationService.Navigating> event is raised when navigating from one piece of content to another.
The content that is being navigated from is added to back navigation history.

You can set <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.ContentStateToSave%2A> with a custom <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.CustomContentState> object to associate state information with content in navigation history.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Navigation.CustomContentState"></xref> object that is associated with the back navigation history entry for the page being navigated from.
Gets the optional data <xref href="System.Object"></xref> that was passed when navigation started.
<xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.ExtraData%2A> can be used to pass context-specific data that is specific to a particular navigation.

<xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.ExtraData%2A> contains a reference to the object that is passed as the second argument when calling either <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationService.Navigate%2A?displayProperty=fullName> or <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationService.Navigate%2A?displayProperty=fullName>.
Otherwise, it is `null`.
The optional data <xref href="System.Object"></xref> that was passed when navigation started.

Indicates whether the navigator (<xref href="System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationWindow"></xref>, <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.Frame"></xref>) that is specified by <xref href="System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.Navigator"></xref> is servicing this navigation, or whether a parent navigator is doing so.

A <xref href="System.Boolean"></xref> value that is `true` if the navigator that is specified by <xref href="System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.Navigator"></xref> is servicing this navigation.
Otherwise, `false` is returned, such as during a nested <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.Frame"></xref> navigation.
Gets a <xref href="System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationMode"></xref> value that indicates the type of navigation that is occurring.
The types of navigation that can occur are:
Navigating to new content (<xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationMode.New>).
Navigating to the previous item in back navigation history (<xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationMode.Back>).
Navigating to the next item in forward navigation history (<xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationMode.Forward>).
Refreshing existing content (<xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationMode.Refresh>).
A <xref href="System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationMode"></xref> value that indicates the type of navigation that is occurring.
The navigator that raised this event.
While <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.Navigator%2A> stores a reference to the navigator that raised this event, the navigator may not have actually initiated the navigation.
To determine whether this navigator did initiate the current navigation, inspect the <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.IsNavigationInitiator%2A> property.
An <xref href="System.Object"></xref> that is the navigator that raised this event
Gets the <xref href="System.Windows.Navigation.CustomContentState"></xref> object that is to be applied to the content being navigated to.

<xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.TargetContentState%2A> will contain a <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.CustomContentState> object if navigating to content in back or forward navigation history that has a <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.CustomContentState> object associated with it.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Navigation.CustomContentState"></xref> object that is to be applied to the content being navigated to.
Gets the [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_uri](~/includes/tlasharptla-uri-md.md)] for the content being navigated to.
You can navigate to content using either an [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_uri](~/includes/tlasharptla-uri-md.md)] or an object.

When navigating to an [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_uri](~/includes/tla2sharptla-uri-md.md)], which occurs when calling <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationService.Navigate%2A?displayProperty=fullName> and <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationService.Navigate%2A?displayProperty=fullName>, <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.Uri%2A> contains the [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_uri](~/includes/tla2sharptla-uri-md.md)] of the content being navigated to.
Additionally, the <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.Content%2A> property will be `null`.
The <xref href="System.Uri"></xref> for the content being navigated to.
If navigating to an object, <xref href="System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.Uri"></xref> is `null`.
Gets the <xref href="System.Net.WebRequest"></xref> object that is used to request the specified content.
<xref:System.Net.WebRequest?displayProperty=fullName> is an abstract base class that encapsulates a Web request, and is protocol agnostic.

For each common protocol, the [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_titlewinfx](~/includes/tlasharptla-titlewinfx-md.md)] includes a class that derives from <xref:System.Net.WebRequest?displayProperty=fullName> and extends it with protocol specific state and behavior, including:

<xref:System.IO.Packaging.PackWebRequest>: [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_uri#plural](~/includes/tla2sharptla-urisharpplural-md.md)] that use the `pack://` scheme to request application data files (see [WPF Application Resource, Content, and Data Files](~/docs/framework/wpf/app-development/wpf-application-resource-content-and-data-files.md)).
<xref:System.Net.HttpWebRequest>: [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_uri#plural](~/includes/tla2sharptla-urisharpplural-md.md)] that use the `http://` scheme to request files from Web servers.
<xref:System.Net.FtpWebRequest>: [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_uri#plural](~/includes/tla2sharptla-urisharpplural-md.md)] that use the `ftp://` scheme to request files from FTP servers.
<xref:System.Net.FileWebRequest>: [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_uri#plural](~/includes/tla2sharptla-urisharpplural-md.md)] that use the `file://` scheme to request local files.
You can both view and modify <xref:System.Net.WebRequest> details.
<xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigatingCancelEventArgs.WebRequest%2A> is `null` when navigation occurs by:
Using the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.WebBrowser> control.
Calling <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationService.Navigate%2A>
Setting <xref:System.Windows.Navigation.NavigationService.Content%2A?displayProperty=fullName>.
Navigating through HTML content in a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Frame>.
Gets the <xref href="System.Net.WebRequest"></xref> object that is used to request the specified content.
